forecast.no_outcome_scenario: North Korea continues missile launches and hostile rhetoric but avoids a nuclear detonation, preserving leverage for later (e.g., around larger exercises or autumn anniversaries), heeding some Chinese restraint, and deciding the political cost-benefit doesn’t favor a test in May–June.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Pyongyang conducts a seventh test at Punggye-ri to validate a new (possibly tactical) warhead design or signal resolve to Washington/Seoul, timed to a perceived provocation or domestic milestone; IMS/CTBTO registers a seismic event consistent with a nuclear explosion and credible sources confirm.
forecast.rationale: Time left is short. The status quo since 2017 has been no nuclear tests, despite repeated assessments since 2022 that Punggye-ri appeared test-ready. That long hiatus, plus the absence of a clear, recurring trigger in May–June, makes “no test” the base case. Historically, DPRK tests cluster around certain political or signaling needs; while May has seen a test (2009), most windows pass without one. Countervailing factors keep the probability above very low: indications since 2022 that the site is reconstituted, DPRK’s continued qualitative nuclear/missile development, and potentially reduced diplomatic costs given deeper ties with Russia and a tense regional environment. With only ~61 days left, even a regime willing to test needs preparatory signals (e.g., tunnel works, cabling, site lockdown) that would likely leak via satellite or allied warnings; absent such signals, odds stay modest. Why not higher: seven-plus years with zero tests, short window, lack of a known imminent trigger, and the regime’s demonstrated willingness to hold leverage. Why not lower: readiness indicators in recent years, regime unpredictability, and the possibility of a sudden political decision to validate new designs. What would move me up: credible satellite imagery of intensified activity at Punggye-ri (vehicle convoys, cabling, ventilation changes), allied intelligence warnings of an imminent test, DPRK state media foreshadowing a qualitative nuclear step, or a sharp escalation cycle (e.g., direct clashes or new sanctions drives) that Pyongyang answers with a detonation. What would move me down: visible de-escalation signals (high-level China-DPRK consultations urging restraint), reporting of technical setbacks at the site, or authoritative assessments that a test window has closed for logistical or seasonal reasons.
